title: Using Data from Earth Observation to Support Sustainable Development Indicators: An Analysis of the Literature and Challenges for the Future
author: Andries, Ana and Morse, Stephen and Murphy, Richard J. and Lynch, Jim and Woolliams, Emma R.
summary: The paper employs a two-step methodology to investigate the societal and economic benefits of the satellite industry and remote sensing applications. The first step involves gathering information from major federal, government, and private space agencies, while the second step entails examining peer-reviewed academic literature using databases such as Scopus and Web of Science. The selected papers come from various domains, including economics, management, agriculture, remote sensing, and others.    The paper discusses the significance of the satellite industry, with more than 76.82% of the world space economy turnover attributed to it. The global satellite industry revenues have shown consistent growth, reaching $206.5 billion in 2016. Various applications of satellites are explored, such as space observations, military operations support, precision agriculture, meteorological forecasting, broadcast services, and enhancing communication networks.    Regarding remote sensing (RS) applications, the technology provides valuable data for understanding environmental phenomena and global developments. RS data offers unique advantages for economists, including access to hard-to-obtain information, high spatial resolution, and wide geographic coverage. The paper identifies four main areas of RS application: military surveillance, environmental analysis, monitoring human activities, and addressing environmental and illegal issues caused by human activities.    The limitations of the study include the absence of cost analysis related to satellite construction and launch, as well as exploring non-satellite aspects of the space economy. Future research could delve into these areas to provide a more comprehensive understanding of the economic benefits of satellite and RS technologies.

title: Economic Assessment of the Use Value of Geospatial Information
author: Bernknopf, Richard and Shapiro, Carl
summary: The paper utilizes a choice experiment methodology to estimate the societal benefits of the geospatial fire management system, specifically focusing on the Sigma-I suite of tools used in managing forest fires in Guatemala's Maya Biosphere Reserve. The key attributes considered in the study are spatial resolution, frequency of reporting, climate forecast, land use/land cover mapping, accuracy, and cost.    The methods involved surveying stakeholders to understand their preferences regarding these attributes of the geospatial fire monitoring tools. Respondents were asked to choose among different combinations of attribute levels to estimate their willingness to pay for improvements in these attributes. The study found statistically significant positive willingness to pay for higher frequency reporting and reductions in false positives in the hotspot monitoring system.    The results suggest that decision-makers value improvements in the ability to detect and respond to forest fires promptly, emphasizing the importance of timely information in fire management. The study provides insights into the nonmarket value of geospatial tools in forest fire management and highlights the potential for continued investment in such technologies in developing countries facing common agricultural fire challenges.

title: Monetising the Savings of Remotely Sensed Data and Information in Burn Area Emergency Response (BAER) Wildfire Assessment
author: Bernknopf, Richard and Kuwayama, Yusuke and Gibson, Reily and Blakely, Jessica and Mabee, Bethany and Clifford, T. J. and Quayle, Brad and Epting, Justin and Hardy, Terry and Goodrich, David
summary: The methods used in this paper involve an economic model applied to assess the societal benefits of geospatial information in decision-making. The value of information (VOI) contained in geospatial data is evaluated by comparing the net benefits of a decision with and without the information. Various technologies are employed for collecting and distributing geospatial data. The economic model for assessing the VOI in geospatial data is applied to three examples:     1. A retrospective model on the environmental regulation of agrochemicals to demonstrate the potential value of geospatial information in regional health policy decisions.       2. A prospective model on the impact and mitigation of earthquakes in urban areas to show how geospatial data can inform dynamic physical processes and their effects on specific income groups.    3. An ongoing examination of a privateâ€“public integrated geospatial information model for ecosystem services markets to reduce environmental externalities by using detailed geospatial data for efficient monitoring and analysis.    The applied economic model involves an interdisciplinary approach incorporating spatial and temporal scientific, technical, and economic data. The geospatial information is used to identify spatial patterns, test hypotheses, and estimate the gain in societal welfare based on better decisions with additional information in the presence of uncertainty. The economic value of geospatial data is assessed by analyzing the net benefits with and without the information in decision-making scenarios. The paper also discusses the economic impacts of geospatial technology in various sectors such as agriculture, resource extraction, environmental hazards, wildfire management, and maritime shipping.

title: The Value of Remotely Sensed Information: The Case of a GRACE-Enhanced Drought Severity Index
author: Bernknopf, Richard and Brookshire, David and Kuwayama, Yusuke and Macauley, Molly and Rodell, Matthew and Thompson, Alexandra and Vail, Peter and Zaitchik, Benjamin
summary: The paper develops a decision framework to quantify the economic value of information from the Gravity Recovery and Climate Experiment (GRACE) satellite mission for drought monitoring. The methods used include the development of a conceptual framework, structured listening sessions with stakeholders, econometric analysis of the contribution of GRACE data to the U.S. Drought Monitor (USDM), and a demonstration of how improved drought monitoring can influence real-world decisions.    The econometric analysis includes estimating the marginal effect of drought on net farm income and corn yield using USDM and GRACE indicators. The models show significant changes in coefficient estimates when GRACE indicators are included, indicating improved goodness of fit. Statistical tests confirm the significance of the GRACE variables in enhancing the models.    The results demonstrate substantial improvements in model fit, as measured by adjusted R-squared, Akaike Criterion, and Bayesian Criterion, when GRACE indicators are added. The models with GRACE indicators reduce the frequency of large prediction errors, leading to economically significant improvements in accuracy.    The paper also simulates the potential impact of using GRACE data in a real-world drought assistance program, highlighting how GRACE information could affect county eligibility decisions and resource allocations. The findings suggest that incorporating GRACE data can lead to more effective drought management and decision-making, potentially resulting in tangible societal benefits.

title: Assessing the Value of Information for Water Quality Management in the North Sea
author: Bouma, J. A. and {van der Woerd}, H. J. and Kuik, O. J.
summary: The paper used a "value of information" approach to demonstrate the cost-effectiveness of using satellite imagery in the burn area emergency response (BAER) protocol. The study compared the costs of producing a burn area reflectance classification (BARC) map and implementing BAER when imagery from satellites (such as Landsat) was available versus relying solely on aerial reconnaissance data.    The case study included evaluations for specific incidents, showing potential savings of up to $51,000 for a wildfire incident. They also estimated potential savings of up to $35 million over a 5-year period by using Landsat imagery for burn severity information in the BAER program.    Various costs were considered, including analyst labor, hardware, GIS software, satellite imagery, and helicopter response. The study showed that using Landsat imagery was the most cost-effective way to input burn severity information into the BAER program.    The analysis demonstrated the cost savings and cost-effectiveness of utilizing satellite imagery in BAER assessments, particularly emphasizing the economic advantages of using Landsat data for burn severity mapping in emergency response situations.

author: Bouma, Jetske A. and Kuik, Onno and Dekker, Arnold G.

title: The Value of Earth Observation for Managing the Great Barrier Reef
author: Bouma, Jetske and Kuik, Onno and Dekker, Arnold
summary: The paper assesses the value of information for water quality management in the North Sea by using a combination of Bayesian decision theory and stakeholder consultation. The analysis focuses on the potential societal benefits of investing in satellite observations for Dutch water quality management.    The study develops a model to quantify the potential contribution of satellite observations to improving decision-making and welfare in the management of eutrophication, harmful algal blooms, and suspended sediment and turbidity in the North Sea. The methodology involves constructing a questionnaire and interpreting the results to estimate the expected welfare impact of investing in satellite observation for water quality management.    The results indicate that, on average, respondents believe that satellite observations would improve water quality monitoring in the North Sea. The expected value of investing in satellite observations is found to exceed the costs, suggesting a positive return on informational investments. However, the outcomes are strongly influenced by the accuracy of the information system and the perceived range of informational benefits.    The study demonstrates the use of Bayesian decision theory in assessing the economic value of information in the context of water quality management. It highlights the importance of considering uncertainties and stakeholder perceptions in evaluating the societal benefits of satellite or Earth Observation data for environmental management.

title: The Value of Earth Observation for Marine Water Quality Management
author: Bouma, J. A. and Kuik, O. J. and {van der Woerd}, H. J. and Dekker, A. G.
summary: The paper developed an analytical framework to estimate the societal benefits of Earth observation (EO) data, specifically focusing on marine water quality management. The analysis combined Bayesian decision theory with an expert-oriented approach to assess the value of informational investments under uncertainty. Two case studies were presented: one concerning potentially harmful algal blooms in the North Sea and the other addressing water quality monitoring in the Great Barrier Reef lagoon.     For the North Sea case study, the expected benefits of EO investments were found to depend strongly on the perceived accuracy of the information system. Respondents indicated that EO data could improve marine water quality monitoring and reduce uncertainty by roughly 50%. The value of EO information in this case was estimated to be 350,000 euro/week if the perceived accuracy was high.     In the Great Barrier Reef case study, respondents expected the accuracy of EO information to be maximally 80%. Depending on prior beliefs and perceived accuracy, the value of EO information ranged from 21.2 million to 82 million USD per year.     The results showed that decision-makers' perceptions of the accuracy of EO data and their prior beliefs about the state of the environment play significant roles in determining the value of EO information for societal benefit in marine water quality management. The approach demonstrated the applicability of combining Bayesian decision theory with expert elicitation to assess the economic benefits of EO data in natural resource management. Further research and application of this methodology to different environmental decision-making contexts were suggested for future work.

title: Bayesian Framework for Assessing the Value of Scientific Space Systems: Value of Information Approach with Application to Earth Science Spacecraft
author: Brathwaite, Joy and Saleh, Joseph H.
summary: The paper employs an expert elicitation approach based on Bayesian decision theory to estimate the societal benefits of Earth observation data for managing the Great Barrier Reef. The study focuses on the importance of Earth observation information, particularly from ocean and coastal color satellite sensors, in providing spatially and temporally dense information on sediment flows. By improving decision-making through better-targeted run-off reduction measures enabled by Earth observation, the paper assesses the economic value of this improved targeting. The analysis suggests that increasing the accuracy of the information is the most effective way for developers of Earth observation information to enhance its added value for managing coral reefs. The study demonstrates that investments in Earth observation data for better managing the Great Barrier Reef can lead to substantial societal benefits, depending on the perceived accuracy of the information and the prior beliefs of decision-makers. The estimated value of information ranges from 37 million aud/year to potentially higher values if the accuracy of EO information is further improved. The results also highlight the importance of updating decision-makers' beliefs to fully realize the economic value of Earth observation data.

title: Empowering Brazilian Unprivileged Communities with High Geotechnological Tools
author: Brito, Patricia Lustosa and Reis, Daniel Nadier Cavalcanti and Brito, Ricardo Lustosa and {de Oliveira Fernandes}, Vivian and Alixandrini, Mauro
summary: The paper titled "The Value of Earth Observation for Managing the Great Barrier Reef" by Bouma, Kuik, and Dekker (2009) utilizes an expert elicitation approach based on Bayesian decision theory to estimate the expected contribution of investments in Earth observation (EO) data for managing the Great Barrier Reef (GBR). The main focus is on how EO can improve decision-making by enabling better-targeted emission reduction measures in the GBR lagoon.    The authors develop a model to optimize emission reductions under different states: emissions from all catchments affecting reef quality or emissions from certain catchments affecting reef quality more. To estimate the societal benefits, they assess the cost savings of improved targeting which could lead to more efficient water quality management.    In order to quantify the value of the information provided by EO data, the authors construct a Bayesian decision framework that considers decision-makers' prior beliefs, the perceived accuracy of the information, and how decision-makers update their beliefs based on the information. By eliciting decision-makers' perceptions of the accuracy of EO information through a questionnaire, the study determines the type-I and type-II errors associated with the information.    The study finds that improving information accuracy increases its value and expands the range of decision-makers willing to invest in the informational service. The estimated value of EO information for managing water quality in the GBR is 13.9 million AUD per year, representing the potential cost savings that could be achieved through more targeted decision-making facilitated by EO data.    The results demonstrate the applicability of Bayesian decision theory in assessing the societal benefits of EO data for environmental management, particularly in the context of complex decision-making processes like water quality management in the GBR. The methodology provides insights into the conditions under which investments in EO data are economically feasible and highlights the importance of information accuracy in enhancing decision-making and realizing cost savings.

title: Economic Potential of Oil Palm Plantation Using Remote Sensing-Based Technology in Indonesia
author: Center for Aerospace Policy Studies, National Institute of Aeronautics and Space (LAPAN), Indonesia} and Diana, Shinta Rahma and Farida, Farida and {Faculty of Economics and Bussiness, UPI, YAI, Indonesia
summary: The paper outlines a Bayesian framework for assessing the value of scientific space systems by quantifying the value of the information these systems provide. The authors propose a methodology to evaluate the system value based on the information it generates and how this information affects stakeholders' decision-making processes.    The framework involves:  1. Viewing space systems as information sources and stakeholders as information recipients.  2. Updating stakeholders' beliefs through information provided by the system to enable better decision-making.  3. Quantifying the value of the system based on the improvement in expected pay-offs due to the information it provides.    The study applies this Bayesian framework to the case of an Earth science satellite designed to provide hurricane information to oil rig operators in the Gulf of Mexico. Probability models of stakeholders' beliefs and economic models of pay-offs are integrated with spacecraft design considerations to evaluate the system's value.    The results indicate clusters of payload instruments that yield higher information value and minimum information thresholds required to justify the system's acquisition. The analysis also considers the cost-value trade-offs to provide insights for program managers into system value generation and lifecycle cost considerations.    The study highlights how the proposed Bayesian framework can help in decision-making processes and system design evaluations based on the societal benefits derived from satellite or Earth Observation data.

title: Operational Use and Impact of Satellite Remotely Sensed Ocean Surface Vector Winds in the Marine Warning and Forecasting Environment
author: Chang, Paul and Jelenak, Zorena and Sienkiewicz, Joseph and Knabb, Richard and Brennan, Michael and Long, David and Freeberg, Mark
summary: The paper discusses the use of high geotechnological tools, such as satellite images, GPS, geobrowsers, collaborative internet maps, and others, to empower unprivileged communities in Brazil. The methodology used by the authors involved searching for Brazilian projects or publications that showcased experiences of poor communities engaged in mapping themselves. The search utilized search engines, collaborative map platforms, and specialized journals to identify and catalog such projects.    Various projects were highlighted, including the use of Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS), geobrowsers, remote sensing products, Geographic Information Systems (GIS), and collaborative mapping. The discussion emphasized the importance of education, local capacity building, intergenerational collaboration, and community engagement in utilizing geotechnologies effectively. The projects demonstrated how these tools could facilitate community empowerment, sustainable development, and participatory decision-making in territorial planning and management.    Overall, the paper suggests that by promoting local engagement, education, and technological literacy, unprivileged communities can harness geotechnological tools to improve their living conditions, address environmental challenges, and advocate for their rights effectively.

summary: The paper "Seeing Our Planet Whole: A Cultural and Ethical View of Earth Observation" by Harry Eyres does not explicitly outline methods used to estimate or quantify the societal benefits of satellite or Earth Observation data. Instead, it provides a holistic view of the historical, cultural, and ethical aspects related to Earth observation.    The paper covers a wide range of topics including the history of cosmology and astronomy, the evolution of environmental ethics, attitudes towards the environment in different cultures and religions, the development of Earth observation technologies, resistance and skepticism towards environmental science, the aesthetic potential of Earth observation, and the concept of environmental democracy.    While the paper does not focus on quantitative methods or economic analyses, it delves into philosophical and ethical discussions related to Earth observation and its implications for society and the environment. Eyres examines the role of Earth observation in the context of the Anthropocene era, human responsibility towards the planet, and the potential of Earth observation data in addressing issues such as the migration crisis and the UN Sustainable Development Goals.    In summary, the paper takes a cultural, ethical, and philosophical approach to understanding Earth observation and its impact on society, rather than using traditional economic methods to measure societal benefits.

title: Knowledge Generation Using Satellite Earth Observations to Support Sustainable Development Goals (SDG): A Use Case on Land Degradation
author: Giuliani, Gregory and Mazzetti, Paolo and Santoro, Mattia and Nativi, Stefano and Van Bemmelen, Joost and Colangeli, Guido and Lehmann, Anthony
summary: The paper presents a conceptual framework for assessing the benefits of a Global Earth Observation System of Systems (GEOSS). The primary aim is to improve the information available to decision-makers at all levels related to human health and safety, protection of the global environment, reduction of losses from natural disasters, and achieving sustainable development.    The methods used in the paper include proposing better international cooperation in the collection, interpretation, and sharing of Earth observation information as a cost-effective mechanism for achieving these aims. The authors suggest that incremental improvement in observing systems will lead to better societal outcomes.    The paper introduces the "benefit chain" concept as a way to assess the benefits and costs of Earth observation. This involves establishing a causal pathway from improved observations to better decision-making and societal outcomes. The authors also propose using order-of-magnitude approaches and qualitative understanding to estimate the incremental costs and benefits of investing in Earth observation systems.    Overall, the paper highlights the importance of assessing the societal benefits of Earth observation systems and provides a framework for evaluating the cost-effectiveness of investing in these systems through international collaboration and improved data sharing.

author: Gleason, Louis

title: Use of Climate Information for Socio-Economic Benefits

title: A Cost-Benefit Analysis of The National Map
author: Halsing, David L. and Theissen, Kevin and Bernknopf, Richard
summary: The paper discusses the importance of using tele-epidemiological data and Earth Observation (EO) technologies to quantify the societal benefits of satellite or Earth Observation data in understanding and documenting pandemics like COVID-19. Here are some key methods highlighted in the paper:    1. **Satellite Data for Tracking Viral Vectors**: The paper proposes the use of satellites and Earth Observation technologies to track viral vectors, such as animals, insects, and bacteria, that may spread diseases like COVID-19. By predicting the movement of potential vectors, a geographic model of virus dispersion can be created to identify areas vulnerable to infection.    2. **Remote Sensing Techniques**: Advanced EO methods like ground-penetrating radar (GPR) and electrical earth resistance can identify concealed mass graves, which are often used in times of public health crises. These techniques help in locating mass burial sites, ensuring a more accurate historical record and documenting the impact of pandemics on different populations.    3. **Real-Time Mortality Analysis**: EO researchers can analyze satellite imagery of mass burial activities to predict mortality rates within countries. This real-time monitoring can help establish a more accurate statistical record of a pandemic's impact, especially in areas where traditional data collection is inadequate or intentionally revised.    4. **Historiographical Concerns**: By utilizing EO technologies, historical researchers can overcome data inequalities in storytelling by measuring the impact of pandemics on civilian populations independent of robust national tracking infrastructures. This ensures a more inclusive narrative of a virus's impact, especially for marginalized communities.    Overall, the paper emphasizes the value of utilizing EO technologies in tracking, documenting, and correcting historical narratives during pandemics, highlighting the importance of a comprehensive and inclusive approach to understanding and addressing public health crises.

title: Earth Observation and the Public Good
author: Harris, Ray and Miller, Lewis
summary: The methods used in this paper focus on the assessment of the societal benefits of using climate information, particularly satellite or Earth Observation data, for socio-economic benefits. The author emphasizes the importance of climate information in addressing global sustainability challenges, particularly in relation to agricultural production and food security. The paper discusses the value of climate information as a public good and highlights the key role it plays in adaptation to and mitigation of climate change.    Several empirical studies are referenced to illustrate the positive impacts of using climate information in various sectors, such as agriculture, drought mitigation strategies, livestock production, and disaster management. The author also highlights the challenges faced by service providers and users in effectively utilizing climate information for economic benefits, including issues related to accuracy, lead time, institutional constraints, decision models, and knowledge gaps.    To address these challenges and promote the use of climate information for decision-making, the paper suggests a multi-disciplinary approach involving collaboration between scientists, users, and policymakers. It emphasizes the importance of outreach programs, educational initiatives, and the development of comprehensive user-focused climate services. The paper also discusses the proposed development of a global framework for climate services (GFCS) to enhance climate risk management and adaptation on a global scale.    Overall, the paper calls for investment in basic research, innovation-driven solutions, and public-private partnerships to support the effective use of climate information for societal benefits. It underscores the importance of improving access to climate services for vulnerable populations and the necessity of overcoming existing challenges to facilitate greater utilization of climate information in decision-making processes.

title: Pricing Policy and Legal Issues: 6th and 7th EOPOLE Workshops
author: Harris, Ray and Olby, Nicola

title: A Method for Estimating the Socioeconomic Impact of Earth Observations in Wildland Fire Suppression Decisions
author: Herr, Vincent and Kochanski, Adam K. and Miller, Van V. and McCrea, Rich and O'Brien, Dan and Mandel, Jan
summary: The paper discusses the main conclusions of the sixth and seventh eopole workshops on pricing policy and legal issues related to Earth Observation (EO) data. The methods used to estimate or quantify societal benefits of satellite or EO data were not explicitly outlined. However, the paper discusses the pricing policies and the value of EO data, which can indirectly inform about the methods used to estimate societal benefits.    1. **Market Analysis**: The Earth Observation sector is described as small, fragmented, immature, and complex. Market analysis reports are cited to highlight the potential growth of the sector.    2. **Price and Value**: The price of EO data is discussed as a function of supplier costs and buyer willingness to pay. The relationship between price and spatial resolution is addressed, along with factors influencing pricing such as geographic area, product accuracy, and delivery time.    3. **European Strategic Considerations**: The paper discusses the importance of pricing as a servant of mission objectives and proposes the use of European structural funds to support EO objectives.    4. **New Business Models**: The potential for new business models in EO is explored, including providing data for free and generating revenue through other means like advertising.    5. **Law and Sovereignty**: The paper delves into the complex relationship between law, policy, and EO activities. It mentions legal frameworks for EO in different regions and the importance of legal instruments in shaping policies.    6. **Civil and Military Context**: Issues related to the availability of high-resolution data, privacy concerns, and the public service nature of EO activities are discussed.    7. **European Community**: The role of the European Community in funding EO activities, public-private partnerships, and the legal frameworks within the EU are highlighted.    Overall, the paper primarily focuses on pricing policies, legal frameworks, and strategic considerations related to EO data. The methods for estimating societal benefits are indirectly addressed through discussions on pricing, value assessment, and the potential growth of the EO market.

title: The Potential Value of Improved Ocean Observation Systems in the Gulf of Mexico
author: Kaiser, Mark J. and Pulsipher, Allan G.
summary: This paper explores the concept of public goods in the context of Earth Observation data. It discusses the characteristics of public goods, such as non-rivalry and non-excludability, and how they apply to Earth Observation missions and programs. The study examines nine different Earth Observation data types and categorizes them based on their rivalry and excludability.    The paper finds that not all Earth Observation data can be classified as pure public goods and suggests that the term "merit goods" may be more appropriate for many Earth Observation data sets. The analysis also highlights the importance of understanding the various degrees of "publicness" in Earth Observation data and the implications for policy and management.    Overall, the study emphasizes the need for a more nuanced approach in categorizing and managing Earth Observation data, taking into account factors such as rivalry, excludability, and the potential societal benefits of different data types.

author: Kenkel, Phil L. and Norris, Patricia E.

title: Assessing the Economic Value of Early Warning Systems
author: Klafft, Michael and Meissen, Ulrich
summary: The paper uses the contingent valuation technique to determine the willingness of Oklahoma farmers and ranchers to pay for real-time mesoscale weather information. The study focuses on the development of a mesoscale network called "Mesonet" that provides improved weather information to agricultural producers. The methods include designing a mail survey of agricultural producers, asking about their willingness to pay for different levels of weather information, and analyzing the data using maximum likelihood methods to estimate willingness to pay based on various producer characteristics.    Key findings include that agricultural producers are willing to pay only a modest fee for improved weather information, with factors such as gross sales, irrigation, and past weather losses significantly impacting willingness to pay. The study also evaluates the aggregate value of the system based on willingness to pay estimates, highlighting the challenges in recovering costs through user fees alone.    Overall, the paper demonstrates the importance of assessing producers' willingness to pay for improved weather information and decision aids in determining the feasibility and sustainability of investment in mesoscale weather networks.

title: A Scalable Earth Observations-Based Decision Support System for Hydropower Planning in Africa
author: Koppa, Akash and Gebremichael, Mekonnen and Hopson, Thomas M. and Riddle, Emily and Boehnert, Jennifer and Broman, Daniel P.
summary: The paper investigates the societal benefits of improved weather observation systems for forest fire management through quantifiable simulation studies. The methods used in the paper include:    1. **Model Development**: A model is developed to assess how improvements in weather observation systems can help reduce burned areas in forests prone to wildfires.    2. **Weather Data Sets**: Two weather data sets based on "rough" and "fine" grids are used to study the impact of data quality on reducing burned areas.    3. **Nesterov Index**: The air patrolling schedule is determined using the Nesterov Index calculated from observed weather data to target and monitor areas at risk of wildfires.    4. **Simulation Studies**: Stochastic models are used to simulate forest fires and assess the sensitivity of the model with respect to the quality of input data.    5. **System of Systems Analysis**: The paper investigates the benefits of integrating different observation subsystems in a comprehensive global Earth Observation System of Systems (SOS).    6. **Data Preprocessing**: The paper preprocesses the weather data to calculate fire danger classes and determine air patrol frequencies based on the Nesterov Index.    7. **Probabilities Assessment**: Probabilities of fire occurrence in forest areas are assessed based on the Nesterov Index calculations.    8. **Sensitivity Analysis**: The model's sensitivity to changes in grid resolution, number of ground weather stations, and observation system design is analyzed.    9. **Optimization**: The paper explores the optimization of weather station locations to enhance the overall performance of forest fire management systems.    Overall, the study uses a combination of mathematical modeling, data analysis, simulation studies, and sensitivity analysis to quantify the societal benefits of improved weather observation systems for forest fire management.

title: The Value of Information: Methodological Frontiers and New Applications in Environment and Health
author: NA
summary: This paper proposes an economic assessment model for evaluating the societal benefits of early warning systems, with a focus on incorporating socio-cultural factors. The paper discusses existing methods for assessing the value of early warning systems, including contingent valuation and cost avoidance calculations. It highlights the challenges and biases associated with contingent valuation and recommends the use of cost avoidance approaches. The model takes into account factors influencing the effectiveness of early warning systems, such as personal and cultural factors, prediction accuracy, and dissemination-related factors. It introduces variables for estimating the economic impact of an early warning system, including factors related to disaster types, system parameters, and the area of coverage. The model calculates the tangible economic value of the system by comparing the benefits (e.g., cost savings from avoided damage) against the costs (e.g., investments, operational costs) associated with the system. The paper emphasizes the need for more research on the relationship between socio-cultural variables and the effectiveness of early warning systems. The proposed model aims to support policymakers and investors in making informed decisions regarding early warning applications.

title: Using Earth Observations to Enhance Water Resources Decision-Making and Disaster Assessment Processes in the United States and the Developing World
author: Lee, Christine M. and Searby, Nancy D. and Hemmings, Sarah N.

title: Data Poverty: A Global Evaluation for 2009 to 2013 - Implications for Sustainable Development and Disaster Risk Reduction
author: Leidig, Mathias and Teeuw, Richard M. and Gibson, Andrew D.
summary: The paper discusses activities within the NASA Applied Sciences Program (ASP) that focus on using Earth observation tools to enhance water resources decision-making and disaster assessment processes. The methods used involve developing applications and capacity-building programs to improve the use of Earth observations in managing water challenges. These activities include projects that focus on water-related issues in the United States and abroad.     The paper outlines several projects within the ASP program, such as:  1. Developing a global flood and landslide monitoring/forecasting application to improve disasters management.  2. Supporting an international, multi-agency effort for famine early warning systems.  3. Developing an application to improve water resources management in a southeastern coastal region.  4. Developing an application to improve flood forecasting in the developing world.  5. Building capacity to use Earth observations through 10-week applied research projects.  6. Training water managers and practitioners to use Earth observations in decision-making processes.    The methods used in these projects involve utilizing satellite data and remote sensing tools, training workshops, hands-on workshops, and online courses to build awareness and capacity to utilize Earth observations for water-related analyses. The projects target various end users/partners such as US aid, World Meteorological Organization, and other national and international entities. The paper also highlights the importance of user engagement, capacity-building initiatives, and collaboration with various stakeholders to address water challenges effectively.

title: Ascribing Societal Benefit to Applied Remote Sensing Data Products: An Examination of Methodologies Based on the Multi-angle Imaging SpectroRadiometer Experience
author: Macauley, Molly K. and Diner, David J.
summary: The paper discusses frameworks for describing societal benefits associated with Earth observations from the Multiangle Imaging Spectroradiometer (MISR). The two primary frameworks analyzed are:    1. **NASA Earth Science Framework:** This framework characterizes the link between NASA Earth science data and their potential contribution to resource management and public policy. It focuses on how Earth observations inform decision support tools that lead to resource management decisions and policy implementations. The framework emphasizes the practical applications of data products beyond their intrinsic science merit.    2. **NRC Framework for the U.S. Department of Energy:** This conceptual framework developed by the National Research Council identifies the benefits of taxpayer investment in energy efficiency R&D. It categorizes benefits into realized benefits, options benefits, and knowledge benefits, allowing for the assessment of tangible and intangible benefits from research.    The paper illustrates how MISR contributes to various societal benefit themes within these frameworks, such as weather forecasting, climate change, land observations, water supply measurement, and air quality monitoring. MISR's unique capabilities in measuring aerosols, clouds, and surface features have demonstrated potential for improving models, evaluating environmental changes, and advancing scientific knowledge in relevant areas.    However, the paper also discusses institutional factors limiting the full realization of MISR's societal benefits, such as its experimental nature, legacy instrument advantages, continuity concerns, limitations in operational use, data latency, lack of software compatibility, and budget constraints. These factors present challenges in leveraging MISR data for operational applications and long-term benefits. The importance of funding, training, and collaboration between Earth science researchers and decision-makers in utilizing Earth observations for practical applications is highlighted.

title: From Science to Applications: Determinants of Diffusion in the Use of Earth Observations
author: Macauley, Molly K. and Maher, Joseph Andrew and Shih, J. S.
summary: The paper provides a framework for measuring the value of information derived from Earth science data, such as satellite observations. The framework aims to guide studies evaluating the societal benefits of investing in these data. The methods discussed in the paper include econometric estimation, hedonic pricing studies, and contingent valuation surveys.     Econometric estimation involves analyzing data to quantify the gains in productivity or output resulting from using Earth science information. Hedonic pricing studies examine how weather or environmental data are reflected in market prices, such as housing prices or agricultural productivity. Contingent valuation surveys aim to directly measure the value people place on Earth science data by asking them how much they would be willing to pay for it.    The paper also discusses the importance of considering factors such as uncertainty, the stakes involved in decisions, the costs of using the information, and the availability of substitutes when estimating the value of information. It emphasizes the need to assess the societal benefits of Earth science data in various applications, such as resource management, environmental protection, and public health.    The methods outlined in the paper offer a comprehensive approach to evaluating the value of satellite and Earth Observation data and can help decision-makers determine the cost-effectiveness of investing in these technologies for societal benefits.

title: The Value of Information: Measuring the Contribution of Space-Derived Earth Science Data to Resource Management
author: Macauley, Molly K.
summary: The paper describes and illustrates frameworks for societal benefits associated with data products from the multi-angle imaging spectroradiometer (MISR). It highlights the importance of ascribing societal benefits to earth science data beyond their intrinsic scientific merit, especially in light of budget reductions for US earth science. The study uses retrospective analysis of MISR data to demonstrate potential societal benefits and provides guidance for benefit descriptions in future earth observation research programs.    The paper outlines two frameworks for describing societal benefits:  1. The NASA's Earth Science (ESA) framework focuses on data products contributing to resource management and policy decisions through decision support tools. It emphasizes connecting earth observations to decision-making processes.  2. The National Research Council (NRC)/Department of Energy (DoE) framework categorizes benefits as realized (tangible benefits), option benefits (opening doors for future benefits), and knowledge benefits (new knowledge gained).    The study identifies various potential societal benefits of MISR data products in areas such as air quality, carbon management, aviation safety, and more. It also discusses limitations of MISR, such as being an experimental instrument, incumbent advantage of existing instruments, data latency, and software interface incompatibilities.    The paper suggests that a combination of these frameworks may be useful for characterizing benefits associated with earth observations in general. It emphasizes the importance of incentives for researchers, resources for practical applications, and the need for a systematic approach to define, pursue, and communicate practical applications of earth observation data to maximize their societal benefits.

title: The Role of Stakeholders in Creating Societal Value From Coastal and Ocean Observations
author: Mackenzie, Bev and Celliers, Louis and Assad, Luiz Paulo De Freitas and Heymans, Johanna J. and Rome, Nicholas and Thomas, Julie and Anderson, Clarissa and Behrens, James and Calverley, Mark and Desai, Kruti and DiGiacomo, Paul M. and Djavidnia, Samy and Dos Santos, Francisco and Eparkhina, Dina and Ferrari, Jos{\'e} and Hanly, Caitriona and Houtman, Bob and Jeans, Gus and Landau, Luiz and Larkin, Kate and Legler, David and Le Traon, Pierre-Yves and Lindstrom, Eric and Loosley, David and Nolan, Glenn and Petihakis, George and Pellegrini, Julio and Roberts, Zoe and Siddorn, John R. and Smail, Emily and {Sousa-Pinto}, Isabel and Terrill, Eric
summary: The methods used in the paper involve a combination of statistical regression analysis and bibliometric methods.     1. **Statistical Regression**: The authors used statistical regression analysis to estimate the effect of factors on the diffusion of applications of Earth observations data over time. They focused on the deployment of Geographic Information Systems (GIS) as a measure of technology adoption and the price of data as a cost factor. By fitting a conventional diffusion curve model, they examined how the adoption of Earth observations data is influenced by these factors. The data used in the regression analysis included the spread of GIS technology from a geospatial technology report and landsat scene prices provided by the U.S. Geological Survey.    2. **Bibliometric Analysis**: The authors utilized citation analysis to assess the reference patterns among scholars in the field. They investigated how often authors referenced each other's work in their publications as an indicator of a growing community of practice. This analysis aimed to understand the development and spread of applications of Earth observations data within the scholarly community.     Additionally, the authors compiled a dataset of peer-reviewed articles from two widely used indices, the Social Science Citation Index (SSCI) and EconLit, covering a wide range of social science disciplines. They categorized these articles based on thematic content and geographic focus, and also considered the instruments used as sources of Earth observations data.     Overall, the research employed a systematic approach to document the diffusion of Earth observations data in social science research, providing insights into the factors influencing this diffusion and the development of a community of practice around these applications.

author: McCallum, I. and Kidd, R. and Fritz, S. and Kraxner, F. and Obersteiner, M. and Shvidenko, Anatoly
summary: The paper titled "Using Architecture Modeling to Assess the Societal Benefits of the Global Earth Observation System-of-Systems" by James N. Martin discusses the architecture modeling approach used by NASA to evaluate the societal benefits of Earth observation systems. The paper focuses on developing an enterprise architecture for Earth science to assess the capacity of scientific instruments in meeting societal needs and investment strategies. The architecture model comprises about 3000 elements involved in Earth science research, including observation sources, sensors, environmental parameters, data products, science models, predictions, and decision-support tools.    The methods used in the paper involve architectural modeling, metamodeling of the Earth observation system-of-systems (EOSS), and the development of an architecture model that can be extended to the Global Earth Observation System-of-Systems (GEOSS). These methods include both traditional and nontraditional systems engineering tools and techniques. The paper describes a process of enterprise architecture development, including problem framing, conceptual schema development, and metamodel creation. The architecture model captures the relationships between societal benefit areas and types of Earth observations to facilitate analysis and assessment.    The paper also presents a case study illustrating how the architecture model can be applied to a specific scenario, such as hurricane prediction. The example demonstrates how the architecture model can be used to identify relevant elements, decision-support tools, and potential outcomes for decision-making related to Earth observation missions.    Overall, the paper outlines a systematic approach to assessing the societal benefits of Earth observation systems through architecture modeling, highlighting the importance of understanding the interactions between various components and their impact on society.

title: Users, Uses, and Value of Landsat Satellite Imagery: Results from the 2012 Survey of Users
author: Miller, Holly M. and Richardson, Leslie A. and Koontz, Stephen R. and Loomis, John and Koontz, Lynne
summary: The study conducted in Banda Aceh, Indonesia focused on assessing the value of Earth observation data in disaster recovery and reconstruction efforts following the 2004 tsunami. The methods used in the study included:    1. Designing and implementing a questionnaire to capture information about the use, sources, and quality of Earth observation data in the relief and reconstruction effort. The questionnaire was administered to various organizations operating in Banda Aceh, with interviews lasting between 30 to 60 minutes.    2. Collecting and analyzing specific cost-benefit examples that demonstrate the value of using Earth observation data. Examples included:     - Cost-benefit of GPS for community-based bathymetric mapping     - Comparison of traditional surveying to orthophotos     - Use of orthophotos for community-based mapping and survey     - Banda Aceh Water Strategy 2007-2030 and short-term action plan     - Digital orthophoto cost-benefit analysis    3. Analyzing questionnaire results to identify trends and challenges in the spatial data situation since the tsunami. Key findings included improvements in spatial data quality, challenges in training and timeliness of data, and the overall benefits of Earth observation data in the relief and reconstruction effort.    4. Providing a summary of cost-benefit examples showcasing significant cost savings and time efficiencies achieved through the use of Earth observation data in various projects related to disaster recovery and reconstruction.    Overall, the study aimed to quantify the societal benefits of using Earth observation data in disaster regions, highlighting the importance and tangible advantages of leveraging such data in relief and reconstruction efforts.

title: Improved Hydrological Decision Support System for the Lower Mekong River Basin Using Satellite-Based Earth Observations
author: Mohammed, Ibrahim and Bolten, John and Srinivasan, Raghavan and Lakshmi, Venkat

title: Landsat Data Ecosystem Case Study: Actor Perceptions of the Use and Value of Landsat
author: Molder, Edmund B. and Schenkein, Sarah F. and McConnell, Abby E. and Benedict, Karl K. and Straub, Crista L.
summary: The paper employed multiple satellite-based Earth observations and traditional station data along with the Soil and Water Assessment Tool (SWAT) hydrologic model to enhance the Lower Mekong River Basin region's hydrological decision support system. A nearest neighbor approximation methodology was introduced to fill the integrated multi-satellite retrieval for the Global Precipitation Measurement mission (IMERG) grid points from 2001 to 2014, together with the Tropical Rainfall Measurement Mission (TRMM) data points for continuous precipitation forcing for the hydrological decision support system.    A software tool was developed to access and format satellite-based Earth observation systems of precipitation and minimum and maximum air temperatures. Model-simulated streamflow utilizing TRMM and IMERG forcing data was able to capture variability better than model-simulated streamflow with in-situ precipitation station data. The study also presented satellite-based and in-situ precipitation adjustment maps for correction in the Lower Mekong region and emphasized the need to adopt satellite-based Earth observations due to data inconsistency, scarcity, and poor spatial representation in the region.    The methods involved developing a suite of hydrological data products, incorporating satellite-based Earth observation systems, in-situ station data, spatial data, and the SWAT hydrologic model to improve water accounting and floodplain management in the Lower Mekong River Basin. The study area included the Mekong River basin from its origin in the Tibetan Plateau to the delta before the South China Sea, focusing on the lower basin. The paper also described the study watershed's soil information data, in-situ data availability, and the hydrological model SWAT used for the research. Additionally, it discussed the calibration and verification of the hydrological model using TRMM and GPM data, as well as the development of the 'NasaAccess' package in R software for accessing and processing NASA Earth observation data products.    In conclusion, the paper demonstrated the utility of satellite-based Earth observations for enhancing hydrological decision support systems in the Lower Mekong River Basin. The research findings emphasize the importance of utilizing Earth observation data to overcome limitations in in-situ data and improve hydrological modeling accuracy in the region. The development of the 'NasaAccess' package streamlines the processing of NASA Earth observation data and facilitates its integration into hydrological models for better water management practices in the study area.

author: Morretta, Valentina and Vurchio, Davide and Carrazza, Stefano
summary: The paper describes a project focused on integrating Earth Observation (EO) data into an enhanced disease surveillance system for dust-related respiratory diseases in the desert southwest of the United States. The project replaces traditional parameters used in dust forecasting models with EO data sets to improve simulations of particulate matter entrainment, concentrations, and movement. The enhanced dust forecasting model is nested within a regional atmospheric model, and simulations are compared to actual dust episodes recorded by atmospheric patterns and ground-based monitoring systems.    Several EO data sets, such as land cover classes, topographic data, soil moisture, and aerodynamic surface roughness, are assimilated into the model to measure hourly, daily, and weekly improvements in dust forecasts. The study aims to optimize dust forecast scenarios for public health authorities, benchmark the benefits of EO data inputs into respiratory healthcare, and enhance the system's reliability and user confidence.    The experimental design involves sequentially running the model with different combinations of assimilated EO data sets to assess their impact on model performance. Challenges in the design include keeping up with new EO data products being released and evaluating their compatibility with the model, as well as dealing with non-linear interactions between data sets and model performance.    The project emphasizes the importance of statistical evidence and validation to convince public health authorities of the benefits of using geospatial technologies in disease surveillance systems. The paper also highlights the need for further research to bring these capabilities to operational status and suggests that public health organizations may need to add qualified information technologists to their staff to fully utilize digital communication technologies.

title: What Is the Economic Value of Satellite Imagery?
author: Raunikar, Ronald P. and Forney, William M. and Benjamin, Susan P.
summary: The paper explores the economic value of satellite imagery, specifically focusing on the societal benefits of using remote-sensing data from satellites like Landsat for monitoring land uses, agricultural production, and nitrate contamination of aquifers. The study demonstrates that utilizing satellite data for modeling relationships among these factors can lead to more efficient agricultural management without compromising groundwater quality. For the case study conducted in northeastern Iowa, it was estimated that the value of remote-sensing information from Landsat and similar satellites could be as high as $858 million Â± $197 million per year, equivalent to a current value of $38.1 billion. The US Geological Survey (USGS) and NASA jointly manage the Landsat program, which has been collecting earth observation data since 1972.    The economic value of satellite imagery is determined by assessing the benefits of using such data for monitoring and managing various environmental and economic factors. The paper discusses the integrated assessment approach used in the study, which combines remote sensing, hydrology, agricultural information, and other environmental data to estimate nitrate pollution levels, evaluate the long-term survival of groundwater resources, and assess the economic value of remote-sensing data in relation to agricultural production and groundwater quality. The paper also mentions a Value of Information (VOI) analysis, which compares the benefits of having high-quality information from satellite data to the benefits of not having it.    Overall, the study highlights the economic significance of utilizing satellite imagery, such as Landsat data, for decision-making related to agricultural production and environmental protection. It suggests that the economic benefits of using satellite data extend beyond the specific case study in northeastern Iowa and could potentially have substantial value if expanded to other regions across the United States.

title: Interactive Model for Assessing Mangrove Health, Ecosystem Services, Policy Consequences, and Satellite Design in Rio de Janeiro Using Earth Observation Data
author: Reida, Jack B. and Wood, Danielle
summary: The paper presents a multi-disciplinary, interactive modeling framework called EVDT (Environment-Vulnerability-Decision-Technology) to advance ecological forecasting and policymaking using Earth observation data. The framework integrates four models: Earth science models of the environment, human vulnerability and societal impact, human behavior and decision-making, and technology design for Earth observation systems.    The methods used to estimate the societal benefits of satellite or Earth Observation data in this case study include tracking and monitoring mangrove extent, health, and vulnerability over time using Earth observation data, cloud computing, and machine learning. The researchers collaborated with experts in different fields, such as biospheric scientists, ecosystem services economists, local research groups, and governmental organizations, to develop the models and analyze the data.    The study area focused on mangrove forests in the Guaratiba area of Rio de Janeiro, where the researchers assessed mangrove health, ecosystem services value, and policy consequences. They used various data sources, including satellite imagery, socioeconomic and demographic data, historical policy data, and previous EO data usage records from government agencies.    In summary, the methods involved integrating different models, collaborating across disciplines, utilizing Earth observation data, and engaging with stakeholders to estimate and quantify the societal benefits of satellite data for decision-making and policy development related to mangrove conservation and management in Rio de Janeiro.

title: A PROFESSIONAL REVIEW FOR INTEGRATION OF EARTH OBSERVATIONS INTO FEWS NET DECISION SUPPORT
author: Ross, Kenton W. and Underwood, Lauren W. and Brown, Molly E.
summary: The paper describes a professional review conducted to elicit Earth Observation requirements for the Famine Early Warning System Network (FEWS NET), which provides early warning support to decision makers responsible for anticipating and responding to famine and food insecurity events. The review focused on operational requirements of FEWS NET end-users to determine qualities of useful remote sensing data and data products, specifically related to rainfall and vegetation predictions.     The methods involved distributing an online questionnaire to more than 40 experts worldwide in 2007, including both FEWS NET end-users and experts in Earth science information content. The questionnaire addressed general requirements, rainfall requirements, and vegetation requirements, aiming to identify and rank environmental variables and spatio-temporal properties needed for Earth science data inputs. Various satellite-based standardized products were considered, such as rainfall estimates from NOAA, vegetation index data from different sources like MODIS and SPOT Vegetation, and temperature data.     Overall, the review found that rainfall data was crucial for famine early warning, followed by crop yield estimates and vegetation data. The responses highlighted the importance of incorporating new data inputs, such as more accurate and higher-resolution vegetation and rainfall datasets, to improve decision-making capabilities. The study utilized a systems engineering approach to assess end-user requirements and potential NASA inputs, with the goal of enhancing the FEWS NET decision support system and reducing food insecurity.

title: Impact of Global Earth Observation-Systemic View across GEOSS Societal Benefit Area
author: Rydzak, Felicjan and Obersteiner, Michael and Kraxner, Florian
summary: The paper presents a methodological framework to measure and analyze the societal benefits of global Earth observation across various societal benefit areas (SBAs) defined by the Group on Earth Observations (GEO). The study employs a systems approach, integration, and aggregation to evaluate the impact of the Global Earth Observation System of Systems (GEOSS) using a system dynamics modeling and simulation technique.    Key methods and steps outlined in the paper include:    1. **Systems Dynamics Modeling**: The Felix model, a system dynamics model, was developed to capture the interdependencies between social, economic, and environmental components of the Earth system, allowing for complex dynamic behavior analysis.    2. **Methodological Approach**: The study involved constructing the Felix model considering nine specific SBAs, calibrating the model to historical data, formulating baseline scenarios, and creating GEOSS scenarios for impact assessment.    3. **Baseline Scenario Construction**: A baseline scenario was developed by extending the model time scale and introducing policy assumptions to mimic a sustainability scenario, acting as a reference for impact analysis of GEOSS improvements.    4. **GEOSS Scenarios**: Six predefined GEOSS scenarios were constructed in multiple SBAs like energy, disaster health, climate, agriculture, and water, each impacting various model sectors and benefit dimensions.    5. **Impact Assessment**: The paper discusses how the dynamic model simulation results provide insights into the impacts of GEOSS improvements across different societal indicators like population dynamics, gross world product per capita, CO2 emissions, and more.    6. **Model Validation**: The Felix model underwent iterative calibration processes to fit historical data, validate the model structure, and assess the plausibility of its performance in explaining observed behaviors.    7. **Felix Simulator**: A user-friendly simulator tool was developed based on the Felix model, enabling users to run illustrative GEOSS scenarios, explore impacts, and support decision-making processes related to Earth observation data.    In conclusion, the paper highlights the significance of data-driven decision-making in shaping a sustainable future through global Earth observation initiatives like GEOSS and emphasizes the potential benefits of improved data availability in various societal aspects.

title: Enhancing Access and Usage of Earth Observations in Environmental Decision-Making in Eastern and Southern Africa Through Capacity Building
author: Shukla, Shraddhanand and Macharia, Denis and Husak, Gregory J. and Landsfeld, Martin and Nakalembe, Catherine Lilian and Blakeley, S. Lucille and Adams, Emily Caitlin and {Way-Henthorne}, Juliet
summary: The paper describes a project aimed at enhancing the access and usage of Earth Observations (EO) in environmental decision-making in Eastern and Southern Africa through capacity building. The main methods used in the project included:    1. Transfer of Technology: Implementing a web-based tool called Early Warning Explorer (EWX) to allow easy processing and visualization of EO data, particularly focusing on rainfall and temperature monitoring using datasets like CHIRPS and CHIRTSmax.    2. Capacity Training: Conducting training sessions for representatives from regional and national environmental service agencies on EO applications through targeted case studies. The training sessions were strategically conducted to address diverse environmental agencies and geographical locations, and the participants were evaluated before each training session to tailor the content to their specific needs.    3. Engagement with Environmental Service Providers: Regular and sustained engagement with environmental service providers to understand their evolving needs and ensure the application of EO to support decision-making. This involved training educators within the organizations to disseminate knowledge further.    4. Applying EO for Improved Environmental Services: The paper provides specific examples of how the capacity-building efforts enhanced the environmental services of agencies such as the Regional Center for Mapping of Resources for Development, Zambia Meteorological Department, Southern Africa Development Community's Climate Service Center (SADC-CSC), and Tanzania Ministry of Agriculture's National Food Security Division (NFSD).    Overall, the project focused on increasing the capability of regional partners to use EO data effectively for environmental decision-making, with a strong emphasis on technology transfer, capacity building, sustained engagement, and application of EO for improved environmental services in the region.

title: Enhancing the Application of Earth Observations for Improved Environmental Decision-Making Using the Early Warning eXplorer (EWX
author: Shukla, Shraddhanand and Landsfeld, Martin and Anthony, Michelle and Budde, Michael and Husak, Gregory J. and Rowland, James and Funk, Chris
summary: The methods described in the paper focus on the development and application of the Early Warning Explorer (EWX) to enhance the utilization of Earth Observation data for improved environmental decision-making, particularly in regions vulnerable to climate risks and with limited in situ data availability. The EWX framework includes three main components: the viewer, the geoengine processing server, and support applications. The viewer interface allows users to visualize Earth Observation data in the form of maps and time series graphs. The geoengine processes the data and provides web services for accessing and manipulating the data. Support applications include a map server, a geoserver instance, and a PostgreSQL database for storage and retrieval of statistics and data sets.    Examples provided in the paper demonstrate how the EWX can be used to monitor and analyze climate-driven extreme events, such as droughts and floods, to support timely decision-making related to food insecurity and flooding impacts. The paper also highlights the regional implementation of EWX at the Regional Center for Mapping of Resources for Development (RCMRD) in Nairobi, Kenya, to facilitate access to regionally focused Earth Observation data for local decision-makers.    Overall, the methods of the paper focus on the development, implementation, and practical application of the Early Warning Explorer technology to support environmental decision-making in regions vulnerable to climate risks.

title: Valuation of Calibration for Satellite Constellations
author: Siddiqi, Afreen and Baber, Sheila and {de Weck}, Olivier L and Durell, Chris and Russell, Brandon and Holt, Jeff
summary: This paper focuses on the valuation of calibration for satellite constellations and the societal benefits derived from satellite or Earth Observation (EO) data. The methods used in the study include:    1. Effective Data Acquired (EDA) Model: This model quantifies data quality and quantity over regions of interest throughout the mission's lifetime. It is utilized for mission design, trade studies, and optimizing calibration station locations to assess the impact and value of calibration.    2. Error Analysis and Analytical Modeling: Error analysis methods are employed to quantify the impacts of calibration on data processing, computation of indices, and other analytical tasks related to remote sensing.    3. Decision Analysis Methods: Decision analysis techniques are utilized to compare the difference in the value of decisions with information quality, represented by false positive and negative error rates. This approach quantifies the impact of calibration on human decisions that influence socioeconomic outcomes.    Overall, the paper aims to establish a conceptual 'data value chain' that tracks the flow of information from data acquisition to eventual applications and decisions. By employing these methods, the study aims to assess and quantify the societal benefits and value of calibration for satellite constellations and Earth Observation data.

title: The Social Innovation Potential of ICT-enabled Citizen Observatories to Increase eParticipation in Local Flood Risk Management
author: Wehn, Uta and Evers, Jaap
summary: The paper explores the potential benefits and challenges of utilizing citizen observatories to enhance e-participation in local flood risk management. The research methodology includes empirical research in two case study locations - one in the UK and the other in the Netherlands. The study analyzes the dynamics of citizen participation in decision making processes related to flood risk management in these areas. It also investigates the extent to which current processes are ict-enabled, looking at the use of technology to facilitate participation.    In the UK case study, citizens are seen as important stakeholders in flood risk management, with active participation encouraged. In the Netherlands, the focus is more on the prevention of floods through infrastructure management, with citizens playing a lesser role. Both cases employ a range of ICTs for communication and information sharing with citizens, although traditional methods like face-to-face interactions remain prevalent.    The research highlights the diverse roles that citizens and authorities assign to each other in the decision-making process, as well as the current use of ICTs for citizen participation. The study suggests that citizen observatories have the potential to improve stakeholder engagement and participation, but their effectiveness in enhancing e-participation depends on the institutional structures and the level of authority granted to citizens by the authorities.

title: Potential Benefits of Coastal Ocean Observing Systems to Alaskan Commercial Fisheries
author: Wellman, Katharine F. and Hartley, Marcus
summary: The paper "Potential Benefits of Coastal Ocean Observing Systems to Alaskan Commercial Fisheries" by Katharine F. Wellman and Marcus Hartley utilizes a case study approach to estimate the potential benefits to Alaskan commercial fisheries from enhancements to the Alaska Ocean Observing System (AOOS). The methods used in the paper involve:    1. **Qualitative and Quantitative Analysis:** The study includes a qualitative discussion of the current and optimal coastal ocean observation systems information scenarios, decision-making processes, and physical outcomes. It also includes a quantitative analysis of economic outcomes based on plausible scenarios.    2. **Assessment Model:** An assessment of the potential value of information from an enhanced AOOS to select Alaskan commercial fisheries is conducted. The value of information is measured as a change in revenue resulting from increased harvest rates and avoidance of overfishing, as dictated by fishery management strategies.    3. **Assumptions and Uncertainties:** The paper explicitly outlines various assumptions and limitations to the economic assessment of the value of an improved AOOS. Uncertainties are addressed, such as whether the proposed changes to the ocean observation program will deliver better data, integrate the data into stock assessment models, improve reliability of models, and be accepted by managers or industry members.    4. **Expected Value Model:** The paper uses an expected value model with hypothetical probabilities to estimate the chance of potential benefits being realized in Alaskan commercial fisheries.    5. **Case Studies Approach:** The study includes case studies of the Bering Sea and Gulf of Alaska groundfish fisheries, and Kodiak king crab fishery. These case studies offer insights into how enhanced AOOS data could potentially contribute to additional annual revenue and prevent stock collapse.    6. **Simulation of Harvest Scenarios:** The paper simulates hypothetical harvest scenarios based on historical data and projections, considering the potential impact of enhanced oceanographic data on fishery management decisions, such as optimizing harvest rates and preventing overfishing.    Overall, the methods used in the paper provide a structured approach to estimating the societal benefits of satellite or Earth Observation data for coastal management, particularly focusing on revenue increases and improved stock assessments in Alaskan commercial fisheries.

title: The Socioeconomic Benefits of Earth Science and Applications Research: Reducing the Risks and Costs of Natural Disasters in the USA
author: Williamson, Ray A and Hertzfeld, Henry R and Cordes, Joseph and Logsdon, John M
summary: The paper explores the potential economic benefits of better information derived from improved scientific data related to natural disasters, especially hurricanes, droughts, floods, and earthquakes. Some key points from the paper include:    1. Improved predictive capabilities from earth science research have contributed to better understanding and forecasting of weather, climate, and natural disasters.  2. Better information allows for more effective planning, response, recovery, and mitigation strategies for natural disasters, leading to reduced economic costs and human casualties.  3. The economic value of providing such information is emphasized, as it can assist in decision-making, risk reduction, and avoidance of losses caused by natural events.  4. The case studies provided in the paper illustrate how improved information from earth science research can lead to economic benefits, such as reducing evacuation costs, preventing damage, and mitigating losses associated with natural disasters.  5. The limitations and challenges in realizing the full economic benefits of improved information are also discussed, including the need for effective dissemination, regulatory measures, and alignment between scientific knowledge and applied use of data.    Overall, the paper underscores the significant economic value of enhanced information derived from earth science research in reducing the impacts of natural disasters and improving preparedness and response efforts.

title: Cloud Services with Big Data Provide a Solution for Monitoring and Tracking Sustainable Development Goals
author: Wu, Bingfang and Tian, Fuyou and Zhang, Miao and Zeng, Hongwei and Zeng, Yuan
summary: The paper explores the potential of integrating crowdsourcing and public Earth Observation (EO) data to monitor and track the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). It suggests that cloud-based big data services that combine crowdsourcing and public EO data offer cost-effective solutions for monitoring and tracking the SDGs, particularly in low-income countries. The challenges discussed include quality control of public EO data, ensuring data accuracy, and integrating different forms of data for SDG monitoring.    The methods used in the paper include:  1. Utilizing cases and examples to explore the potential of crowdsourcing and public EO data for monitoring and tracking the SDGs.  2. Discussing the role of cloud-based big data services in integrating crowdsourcing and public EO data for SDG monitoring.  3. Highlighting the challenges of using cloud services and big data for monitoring the SDGs, emphasizing the importance of validation and quality control of public EO data.  4. Exploring the functionalities and models needed for cloud services tailored to specific countries or topics to support national or international organizations in monitoring and tracking the SDGs.     There are opportunities and challenges associated with using cloud services with big data for monitoring the SDGs. Some opportunities include providing cost-effective and timely data for SDG monitoring, enabling public participation, and improving transparency. Challenges include ensuring data quality through proper validation and quality control, overcoming data collection limitations, and customizing cloud services to meet specific monitoring needs for different countries or thematic areas.

title: Satellite Earth Observation Value Added Services in the Nigerian Economy. ISNET
author: Zahrah Naankwat Musa} and {Halilu A. Shaba
summary: The paper explores the value-added services provided by satellite Earth observation (SEO) companies in the Nigerian economy. The methods used in the study include an assessment of the needs, current status, and future opportunities for small-to-medium enterprises to offer value-added satellite remote sensing services in Nigeria. The authors discuss the role of both the public and private sectors in utilizing satellite remote sensing techniques and geographic information systems for environmental monitoring, disaster forecasting, and resource management. The study examines the various environmental problems faced by Nigeria, such as desertification, flooding, erosion, oil spillage, and deforestation, and how satellite Earth observation data can be used to address these challenges.    The research highlights the activities of the Nigerian National Space Research and Development Agency (NASRDA) in utilizing satellite imagery for projects related to environmental monitoring, food security, and coastal area management. The study also presents a list of private SEO companies in Nigeria, their geographical distribution, and the types of services they offer, including hydrologic services, geologic applications, waste management, and environmental monitoring. The authors discuss the future opportunities for small to medium enterprises in the SEO sector, particularly in addressing environmental issues in the northern part of Nigeria, such as desertification and oil spill monitoring.    Overall, the paper emphasizes the importance of satellite Earth observation data in addressing environmental challenges in Nigeria and highlights the potential for private sector growth in providing value-added remote sensing services to support sustainable development efforts.
