title: A User-Driven Approach to Determining Critical Earth Observation Priorities for Societal Benefit
author: Zell, Erica and Huff, Amy K. and Carpenter, Adam T. and Friedl, Lawrence A.
summary: The paper presents a user-driven approach to determining critical Earth observation priorities for societal benefit by conducting a cross-sectoral meta-analysis of observation priorities across different areas. The methodology involves two stages: first, critical observations for each societal benefit area are determined based on user needs extracted from publicly available documents, such as journal articles and reports. In the second stage, an ensemble of four statistically robust methods is used to prioritize the observations across multiple benefit areas, considering their criticality and commonality.    The study identifies 152 critical Earth observation priorities, with the top 10 observations being precipitation, soil moisture, surface air temperature, land cover, surface wind speed, vegetation cover, surface humidity, urbanization, vegetation type, and surface wind direction along with sea surface temperature. These priorities are important for assessing the cost-effectiveness of investments in Earth observation systems and determining investment options.    The paper highlights the importance of understanding diverse and evolving user needs to maximize Earth observation benefits for society. It also emphasizes the need for a coordinated approach to prioritize Earth observation priorities and engage stakeholders in decision-making processes. The results provide a foundation for engaging data providers and users in aligning observation priorities to maximize societal benefits and address global challenges such as climate change and disaster management.

title: Future Earth Observation Strategy for Societal Benefits
author: Zhou, Guoqing and Baysal, O.
summary: The paper discusses the future Earth observation strategy for societal benefits, focusing on the use of the Future Intelligent Earth Observing System (FIEOS) for gathering and disseminating valuable information to users. The methods used in the paper include:    1. Implementing strategies for a seamless integration of diverse components into a smart, adaptable Earth observation satellite system to enhance human health, safety, welfare, and environmental protection.      2. Utilizing a networked system of satellites with high-speed optical and radio frequency links to collect data from various sensors onboard each satellite.    3. Introducing an event-driven Earth observation approach where each sensing system independently collects and analyzes data using its own sensors and processors, and collaborates with other satellites to focus on specific events.    4. Enhancing weather forecasting capabilities by providing different levels of weather forecasting data scales and improving the accuracy of forecasts for various applications such as agriculture, disaster management, and health.    5. Supporting sustainable agriculture by using Earth observation data to monitor and predict trends related to food production, climate conditions, and land use, enabling informed decision-making for agriculture management.    6. Implementing an Earth observation system that serves a broad range of user communities, including managers, researchers, policymakers, and the general public, to provide timely and relevant information.    7. Enabling lay users to access satellite data easily and interactively through portable devices, thus empowering them to receive real-time information about their surroundings.    Overall, the methods described in the paper aim to showcase how the FIEOS can significantly improve societal benefits by enhancing decision-making processes, improving disaster management, supporting sustainable agriculture, and providing valuable information to various user groups.

title: Benefits of the Free and Open Landsat Data Policy
author: Zhu, Zhe and Wulder, Michael A. and Roy, David P. and Woodcock, Curtis E. and Hansen, Matthew C. and Radeloff, Volker C. and Healey, Sean P. and Schaaf, Crystal and Hostert, Patrick and Strobl, Peter and Pekel, Jean-Francois and Lymburner, Leo and Pahlevan, Nima and Scambos, Ted A.
summary: The paper discusses the benefits of the free and open landsat data policy implemented by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) in 2008. The methods used to estimate or quantify the societal benefits of satellite or Earth Observation data include analyzing the increase in landsat data usage post-2008, measuring the number of downloads and publications related to landsat data, assessing economic benefits of open access landsat data, examining the role of landsat in global archive consolidation, investigating the use of landsat data in non-federal cloud computing archives, exploring new opportunities enabled by free and open landsat data policy, and discussing how time-series analyses with landsat data have advanced remote sensing science and applications.    The methods encompass analyzing trends in landsat data usage, economic assessments of landsat data, collaborations on data consolidation and interoperability, exploration of landsat data in cloud computing environments, and investigations into new applications and scientific advancements facilitated by access to landsat data. The paper highlights the significant impact of the free and open landsat data policy on increasing access to landsat imagery, fostering scientific research and applications, and promoting international collaboration in Earth Observation efforts.
